Identification.LongTitle: An Act respecting the Royal Canadian Mint

Section.Text: This Act may be cited as the Royal Canadian Mint Act.

Definition.Text: base metal means any metal other than precious metal;
Board means the Board of Directors of the Mint appointed under this Act;
circulation coin means a coin composed of base metal that is listed in Part 2 of the schedule and that is put into circulation in Canada for use in day-to-day transactions;
Master means the Master of the Mint;
Mint means the Royal Canadian Mint established by this Act;
non-circulation coin means a coin composed of base metal, precious metal or any combination of those metals that is not intended for circulation and that is listed in Part 1 of the schedule;
precious metal means gold, silver, platinum or any of the platinum group of metals.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may designate a member of the Queen’s Privy Council for Canada to be the Minister for the purposes of this Act.

Subsection.Text: The Master of the Mint and such other persons as constitute the Board of Directors of the Mint are hereby incorporated as a body corporate under the name of the Royal Canadian Mint.
The objects of the Mint are to mint coins in anticipation of profit and to carry out other related activities.
However, the Mint shall not anticipate profit with respect to the provision of any goods or services to Her Majesty in right of Canada, including the minting of circulation coins.
The head office of the Mint shall be in the National Capital Region as described in the schedule to the National Capital Act.
The authorized capital of the Mint is forty million dollars, divided into four thousand shares of ten thousand dollars each.
The Governor in Council may, by order, approve the purchase by the Minister of shares of the Mint and the payment therefor out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The shares of the Mint are not transferable and when issued to the Minister in accordance with this Act shall be registered in the books of the Mint in the name of the Minister and held by the Minister in trust for Her Majesty in right of Canada.
No shares of the Mint may be issued otherwise than as expressly authorized by this Act.
The Mint shall, at the request of the Minister after consultation with the Board, redeem such number of shares issued to the Minister in accordance with this Act as the Minister may direct.
The price to be paid for each share redeemed by the Mint pursuant to subsection (1) is the issue price of the share.
In carrying out its objects, the Mint has the rights, powers and privileges and the capacity of a natural person and may in particular

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: procure the incorporation, dissolution or amalgamation of subsidiaries and acquire or dispose of any shares in them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: acquire and dispose of any interest in any entity by any means; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: generally do all things that are incidental or conducive to the exercise of its powers with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: coins of the currency of Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: coins of the currency of countries other than Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: gold, silver and other metals, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: medals, plaques, tokens and other objects made or partially made of metal.

Subsection.Text: In addition to the powers under section 21 of the Interpretation Act, the Mint may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: acquire, hold and alienate real property or any interest therein; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make grants in lieu of taxes to any municipality in Canada in amounts not exceeding the taxes that might be levied by that municipality in respect of real property under the administration and control of the Mint if the Mint were not an agent of Her Majesty.

Section.Text: The Mint is for all its purposes an agent of Her Majesty in right of Canada.
The Governor in Council may authorize the issue of non-circulation coins of a denomination listed in Part 1 of the schedule.

Section.MarginalNote: Amendment to Part 1 of the schedule
Section.Text: The Governor in Council may, by order, amend Part 1 of the schedule by adding or deleting a denomination of a non-circulation coin.
The Mint may determine the characteristics, other than the design, of any denomination of a non-circulation coin.
The Minister may determine the design of any denomination of a non-circulation coin.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, by order, authorize the issue of circulation coins of a denomination listed in Part 2 of the schedule.
The order must specify the characteristics for that issue of coin.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may determine the design of any circulation coin to be issued.

Section.MarginalNote: Amendment to Part 2 of the schedule
Section.Text: The Governor in Council may, by order, amend Part 2 of the schedule by amending any characteristic of a circulation coin.

Section.MarginalNote: Coins to be delivered to Minister of Finance

Subsection.Text: All coins of the currency of Canada that are produced at or supplied by the Mint shall be delivered to the Minister of Finance or such person as the Minister of Finance may designate.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Storage, preparation and movement of coins
Subsection.Text: The Mint shall comply with such instructions as the Minister of Finance may give respecting the storage of coins of the currency of Canada or the preparation and movement of shipments of such coins to or from the Mint.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Payments to Mint to be made from C.R.F.
Subsection.Text: Payments for the production, storage, preparation or movement of coins of the currency of Canada shall be made out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund on the authorization of the Minister of Finance.

Section.Text: The Board of Directors of the Mint shall consist of not less than nine and not more than eleven directors, including the Chairperson and the Master.
The Chairperson shall be appointed by the Governor in Council to hold office during pleasure for any term that the Governor in Council considers appropriate.

Section.MarginalNote: Appointment of Master of the Mint

Subsection.Text: The Master shall be appointed by the Governor in Council to hold office during pleasure for such term as the Governor in Council considers appropriate.
The Master is the chief executive officer of the Mint and shall devote the whole of his time to the business of the Mint.

The Board may authorize one of its directors or an officer of the Mint to act as Master in the event that the Master is absent or incapacitated or if the office of Master is vacant but no person so authorized shall act as Master for a period exceeding sixty days without the approval of the Governor in Council.

Section.Text: Each director, other than the Chairperson and the Master of the Mint, shall be appointed by the Minister, with the approval of the Governor in Council, to hold office during pleasure for a term not exceeding four years that will ensure, as far as possible, the expiration in any one year of the terms of office of not more than one half of the directors.

Subsection.Text: Each director appointed under section 11 must have experience in the field of metal fabrication or production, industrial relations or a related field.

A person is not eligible to be appointed or to continue as a director of the Mint if the person is not a Canadian citizen ordinarily resident in Canada or if, directly or indirectly, the person is engaged in any undertaking involving or associated with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the production or distribution of copper, copper alloy, nickel or precious metals;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the purchase, production, distribution or sale of coins or coin operated devices; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the vending of goods and services by means of coin operated devices.

Subsection.Text: Where any interest prohibited by subsection (2) vests in a director by will or succession for his own benefit, the director shall, within three months thereafter, absolutely dispose of the interest.

Section.Text: A director on the expiration of his term of office is eligible for re-appointment to the Board in the same or another capacity.

The Governor in Council may, on such terms and conditions as the Governor in Council may prescribe, appoint a temporary substitute director if a director, other than the Master, is unable at any time to perform the duties of office by reason of absence or incapacity.
Where the office of a director becomes vacant during the term of the director appointed thereto, the Governor in Council may appoint a director for the remainder of that term.

Subsection.Text: The directors shall be paid such salary as is fixed by the Governor in Council and shall receive such benefits as are fixed by the Board.

Each director is entitled to be paid by the Mint such travel and other expenses incurred by the director while absent from his ordinary place of residence in the course of his duties under this Act as may be fixed by by-law of the Mint.
The Mint may appoint such officers, agents and employees as are necessary for the proper conduct of the work of the Mint.
The remuneration of officers, agents and employees of the Mint shall be a charge against the revenues of the Mint.

Section.MarginalNote: Master, officers and employees not part of federal public administration

Subsection.Text: The Master, officers and employees of the Mint are not part of the federal public administration but shall be deemed to be employed in the federal public administration for the purposes of the Government Employees Compensation Act and any regulations made pursuant to section 9 of the Aeronautics Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Master and employees deemed employed in public service
Subsection.Text: The Master, officers and employees of the Mint shall be deemed to be employed in the public service for the purposes of the Public Service Superannuation Act, and the Mint shall be deemed to be a Public Service corporation for the purposes of that Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Contracting powers not limited by collective agreements
Subsection.Text: No collective agreement entered into by the Mint with its employees pursuant to Part I of the Canada Labour Code shall prohibit or limit the power of the Mint to enter into contracts with any person to provide for the procurement by the Mint of any goods or services from that person or the minting of coins by that person.

Section.Text: The Board may make by-laws respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the duties and conduct of officers, agents and employees of the Mint;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions of employment and the fixing of the remuneration of officers, agents and employees of the Mint;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the time and place for the holding of meetings of the Board, the quorum at those meetings and the procedure in all business at those meetings; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: generally the conduct and management of the affairs of the Mint.

Subsection.Text: The Mint may, for the attainment of its objects, borrow money from the Consolidated Revenue Fund or any other source, but the total amount outstanding at any time may not exceed 75 million dollars or such greater amount as may be specified in an appropriation Act.
The Minister of Finance may lend money to the Mint from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The Mint shall not enter into any particular transaction to borrow money pursuant to subsection (1) without the approval of the Minister of Finance with respect to the time and the terms and conditions of the transaction.
The Auditor General of Canada is the auditor of the Mint.
The Auditor General of Canada shall inspect the inventories of stores and metals of the Mint at least once in each year.
